title: Confirming Appointments and Meetings

sections.title: Scheduling and Confirming Meetings
sections.content:
In a professional environment, confirming a meeting via email is essential. You must check availability and confirm the time and place.

- **Checking Availability**: Use questions to see if someone can meet.
- **Confirming**: Re-stating the time and date to avoid confusion.
- **Rescheduling**: Suggesting a new time if you are busy.

sections.title: Key Phrases for Scheduling
sections.content:
- **Are you available on...?**: ¿Estás disponible el...?
- **Does Tuesday work for you?**: ¿Te viene bien el martes?
- **I can confirm the meeting.**: Puedo confirmar la reunión.
- **I am busy at that time.**: Estoy ocupado a esa hora.
- **Please let me know.**: Por favor, házmelo saber.

sections.title: Grammar: Present Simple (Questions and Negation)
sections.content:
We use the Present Simple to talk about schedules and availability.

- **Questions (Do/Does)**:
  - *Do you have time on Monday?*
  - *Does the meeting start at 10:00?*
- **Negation (Don't/Doesn't)**:
  - *I don't have the calendar here.*
  - *She doesn't work on Fridays.*

sections.title: Meeting Vocabulary
sections.content:
- **Appointment**: Una cita (médica o profesional).
- **Meeting**: Una reunión.
- **Schedule / Calendar**: Horario / Calendario.
- **Available**: Disponible.
- **Busy**: Ocupado/a.

objectives: Ask for and confirm professional meetings via email
Use Present Simple in questions and negations for scheduling
Identify common vocabulary related to office calendars and appointments
